IN THREE ACTS

The Compositions are as follows:

TO
EUGENE H. GARNETT
WHO HAS HELPED TO MAKE MY
MIDWINTER NIGHT'S DREAM
AND OTHER DREAMS
COME TRUE
MASTER WILL OF STRATFORD

list.head: CHARACTERS
list.item: WILL SHAKESPEARE, nearly twelve years of age
ROBIN GOODFELLOW, leader of the Pucks.
FRIAR TUCK, ROBIN HOOD and other morris-dancers.

div1.p: (See Notes, post, for description of morris-dance.)

row.cell: Scene: Stratford-on-Avon and neighborhood, 1575 A. D.

div1.p: The Prologue opens New Year's Eve, and the Epilogue New Year's morning. Acts I, II, and II, present the dream during that interval.

div2.head: PROLOGUE
div2.stage: SCENE: The Kitchen in JOHN SHAKESPEARE'S house, Henley Street, Stratford-on-Avon, on New Year's Eve. In center rear, a door. At right of door, an oblong small-paned window, its sill, about three feet from the floor, bearing a prim row of potted plants. Right wall, center, a large open fireplace in which is a black pot over a low fire. A high-backed settle is at right and left of fireplace. A seat extends beneath the window from the settle at right rear corner of room. The seat of settle at right of fireplace raises. At right of door a clock stands; at left of door, a table. A basket of apples is on the table and above are shelves holding copper utensils. At rear left, a large churn. At center left, a door. At center front, a small table covered with an unbleached linen strip and bearing a bowl of milk, a spoon, a plate of bread and a dish containing small cakes. A lighted candle is on this able and another on the table at rear. At right front is a table prepared for ironing, with a basket near containing dampened clothes. The ironed garments are on the settle at left of fireplace. A medium sized basket hangs on the wall. A few chairs complete the furnishings.

MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE is ironing. She listens, puts down her iron and going to the door looks anxiously without. Se closes the door. The clock strikes seven. She glances at the clock, then goes to the window. Seeing someone approach, she opens the
door and admits BETSY carrying her baby brother, DICKUMS.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Bless my heart, if it isna Betsy and the wee Dickums! Come you in, Betsy girl.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.stage: [With a curtsy.]
sp.p: Good den, missus.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: What brings the two of you out tonight, child? Dickums should have been tucked in this long while.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: It war lonesome enough sittin' in the dark to save candles, wi' naught but the two on us--an' him asleep; so I clapped a biggen on his head, and an old slop 'round him, an' here we be!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.stage: [Resuming her ironing.]
sp.p: Are all your folk away?

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: Ah-yea, missus. There be goin's-on at our cousin's this New Year's Eve. Dickums is such a wee dilling, an' me such a strappin' lass, I bide at home an' do the motherin' o' him.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: And a good little mother you are, with ever a babe in your arms or one tagging at your heels.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: I've had little brothers an' sisters to give drinks to by night an' wallops to by day, ever sin' I war knee-high to a stagger-bob.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: You are a busy lass, Betsy.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: There be constant someone a-yelpin' for a tot o' milk or a shive o' summat, or bits an' bobs to do for mother. When I tell your Will, missus, how forewearied I get, he sez to me, "Betsy," sez he, "you shoodna forget to jog up your fancy. Fancy 'ud liven you prodigious," sez he.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.stage: [Ceasing her it ironing.]
sp.p: Yea--that is like my laddie. [Resumes ironing.] I canna tell what is keeping him so late. He should have been back by six o' the clock.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: Mayhap he went by Charlecote way. They do be a-sayin' the Queen is mekin' a day's visit to Sir Thomas and Lady Lucy. Her hankers arter a morsel o' quiet now an' then.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: But Willie isna one for alliance and making his mother longful for him. Sit you up by the fire, Betsy, and have an apple.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: I maut take a dab for Dickums.
sp.stage: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE passes the basket of apples to BETSY

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Here are some scrumps and apple-johns, and one or two leather-coats and sourings. Help yourself right freely, lassie.
sp.stage: [BETSY takes a couple of apples eagery.]

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: An' I do be thinkin', misses, as how Dickums maut relish a pikelet.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Marry, to be sure. Have some cakes, and welome.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.stage: [Eating heavily.]
sp.p: Dickums yent a scraily babe, full o' doctor's stuff. A dab or a dollop's all the same to Dickums. The wee lamb's a-sleepin' so I maut as well eat the apples an' pikelets mesel'--we shoodna be wasteful.
sp.stage: [She puts him on the settle besde her. There is a knock.]

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p:
Who comes knocking, wonder? I hope it is no fell
news about my laddie. [She opens the door and speaks in amazement.] Sir Thomas Lucy! [She curtsies with dignity.] Your pardon, Sir Thomas, come you in.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.stage: [Entering.]
sp.p: Where is John Shakespeare?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: He and some other o' the burgesses, Sir, have gone to Coventry. [Sir Thomas taps the floor impatiently.]

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Beshrew me! that is vexing.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Mayhap I can serve you, sir.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Yea, you can--by keeping your slacken-twist of a son at home!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: A slacken-twist? My laddie?

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Yea, your laddie--the one they call Will.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: What harm do you seek to fasten on him, sir?

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: He has been snaring pheasants in my park--caught in the act with a bird in his arms.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: My boy has great love for creatures and gets together the maimed and ailing that he may nurse them till they be sound again.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: No doubt he snares that he may cure.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: You have a bitter tone, Sir Thomas, and my lad is a good lad.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Good lad, or bad lad, keep him away from Charlecote. I was passing your house and have troubled myself to give you warning. If your young giddy-pate so much as take a pace on my land, or look at one of my pheasants, be shall be punished soundly.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: He were a poor spirited lad if he so much as went within breathing-space o' your grounds. My heart is built in the shape of a W. I believe in my Will.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p:
Believe, an it suit you, but mark what I say, and your bold bantling as well: if ever he cross my path to
give me offense, be it tomorrow or a score of years hence, I shall deal him a double dose for good measure.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: You are a liberal apothecary when it comes to double doses. Good e'en to you.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Woman,--

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Your pardon, sir, I have rare fondness for the last word, and my tongue hangs like a clapper in the middle o' my mouth.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: I tell you--

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Good e'en to you, sir. Can you find your way out? [She holds open the door and Sir Thomas scowls as he goes toward it.]

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: I have this to say--

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Be careful o' the step. That's right. [SIR THOMAS disappears and she opens the door still wider.] Whew! Condemn me for a chatterpie if I do not have to air the place of the man's pirit. There's fell need for the perfumer.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.stage: [Who has been all eyes for Sir Thomas and teeth for her dainties.]
sp.p: Yond be a brawlin', naggin' pickthanks, forever gettin' things all of a pother. [Crooking her fingers.] Wotna I like to set my ten commandments in his face? These apples and pikelets do be fine and toothsome, missus.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Help yourself, lassie.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: I maut be takin' a bittock, leastways a spot o' pikelet for Dickums.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: What can be keeping my laddie? [A figure runs past the window and through the open door. It is the young Shakespeare. She throws her arms about him.]
Will!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Yes, Mother, here am I, late o' the clock but early o' my desire. [He places his cloak, which he has carried bundle-wise, on the settle.]

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.stage: [Closing the door.]
sp.p: What mean you, laddie?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: My desire bade me stay till I could turn tailor and take fresh measure of a man and, having measured him, make new garments to fit him.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Ay, lad, I catch your meaning.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Good even, Betsy.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: Good den, Will.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: The man whose measure I would take would find himself wearing, 'stead o' trunks large enough for Hercules, pinnies to fit Betsy's Dickums.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: I ken the man.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Yes, Mother.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKSPEARE
sp.p: He was here and mortal inflamed against you, laddie.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Did he call me poacher?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Ay, that he did.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: And you--what said you, Mother?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: I said my lad wouldna poach and Willie, an I saw you do it with my own eyes, I wouldna believe it.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I must tell you what befell your scapegrace son.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Eat your bit of supper at the same time, laddie, and I'll finish some lated ironing. I canna rest till my work is done, even if it does make me iron of a New Year's Eve. And on the morrow I shall start the first day of the year in right proper fashion, by churning.
sp.stage: [She has been getting ready to iron and Will has seated himself.]

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I meant to come straight home after I left Charlecote. I started by way of Tiddington Road and got as far as the bridge, but was so brimmed with heated thoughts I crossed the Meadows and went up by the Brake to Luddington.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: And did the walk cool your hot thoughts?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p:
Ay, when I came back as far as the footbridge by the
Mill and saw trinity spire against the sky like an arch-angel's finger, I felt cool and soft in my thoughts and ready to come home to you.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: The home nest's the place for bruised wings. But tell us o' the happenings at Charlecote.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I had heard it said the Queen and her ladies had come for a peaceful New Year's even, and had ridden forth for an airing. You know how I relished the sight of our Queen at Kenilworth last July, so I wandered up Charlecote way, hoping fora glimpse of her.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: None could blame you for that.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: I war a-motherin' Dickums or I maut 'a gone.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Whilst I dallied, pretending the hedge was white with bloom instead of snow, a pheasant half hopped, half flew into the path before me, one wing broken and hanging pitifully.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: The poor creature!

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: They say pheasants do be mortal fine eatin'.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I reached for the bird to ease its sufferings; but, thinking I meant mischief, it led me a spanking chase. Before I was aware, we were in the Charlecote grounds and I had just seized the bird when the keeper clapped his hand on my shoulder.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: My faith! these be some doin's.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: What did he to you, laddie?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: He believed not word of my story and hauled me, pheasant and all, to the high road. We had no more than gained it before who should come riding up but--

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: The Queen! Lawk-a-dingin's, the Queen hersel'!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Sir Thomas Lucy!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Ay, both, and a small party of ladies and gentlemen. They drew rein and Sir Thomas inquired what the pother was about.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: My poor lad!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: He has but a handful of pheasants and sets such store by them he was stirred to a rage at the keeper's tale. The keeper thrust his hand into my doublet and drew out a cord. Then of a certainty they believed I had been snaring.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: How came you by the cord?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I had it for top-spinning.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: Whut did they to you? An' whut did you to they?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: When I saw they had writ poacher over me in tall letters I asked justice of the Queen.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: God mend me! Spoke ye to the Queen?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: What said you, lad?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.stage: [Laughing.]
sp.p: 'Twas as good as the play. I said: "Your Majesty, were I poacher and you near 'tis not pheasants I should pilfer." "And why so, youngling?" "Marry, I should try to poach a hare and not a pheasant." "Why a hare?" asked the Queen. "I should try to poach a hair from your Majesty's golden fleece," quoth I. "Oho, my March-chick, you are a Jason indeed!" she said, and fell to laughing.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: My boy! how could you--to the Queen!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: A queen at best is but flesh and blood, and wit may be royal wherever 'tis found.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: On, on, Will! whut more did ye?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Well, the upshot was she asked Sir Thomas to forgive this offense and let me have the bird to coax back to strength.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Said she those words: forgive this offense?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p:
Oh, Mother, there's the rub! She gave me my re-
lease yet believes me guilty. Were she the Queen I held her she would have known I spoke true.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Ay, Willie.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: Whut 'came o' the bird?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: 'Tis here.
sp.stage: [He goes to the settle and opens his cloak, displaying the pheasant.]

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Put the poor thing in this.
sp.stage: [She hands him the basket from the wall. WILL puts the pheasant in the basket and places it on the hearth.]

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: It war a fearsome adventure. It mun be grand to go adventurin'. Things be mortal dull most whiles.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: What have I told you, Betsy? Rouse your fancy and adventures will hap as thick as bees around the honey-pot.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: I caunt see whut use fancy be to a body.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: It makes you see stories in men's eyes.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: That's brave to say, but whut 'ud a body's fancy do for a dilling like Dickums?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: An you tire thinking on him as a babe, think on him as a man.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: A man! Dickums! That'd take more nor fancy--that'd take a prophet.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Not a prophet but a play-actor. Truly the least has his part to play. Dickums is a mewling babe in your arms, yet will he one day start for school, filling himself with Latin roots heavy for his digestion.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Then, ere you know, will he be courting the lasses and, though their locks be coarse and straight as old Roan's tail, making rhymed nonsense to their silken tresses.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Next will he be man, slaying and slashing with reckless blade.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Yea--and so will he act his part, on through middle age, and old age, and the old-old age that joins itself to babyhood.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: That makes a circle o' life--a huge teething-ring on which men cut their wisdom. Ay, Betsy, your baby brother is become the hero of a tale.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: My wee lamb? Ho, lamb! ŏŏt like to be the hero of a tale?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Mock me not, Betsy. I shall be a weaver one o' these days and make whatsoever pattern I choose. I could make you into a merry shepherdess, or I could even make you into a princess,--an I would.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: Princess! me!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Ay, you. Mayap I shall.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: I wotna care whut you made o' me, Will, so I be lass wi' time now an' then for play.
sp.stage: [There is a rap on the window pane. The face of a pedlar appears.]

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: 'Tis the pedlar I saw on Clopton Bridge,--dumb as a fish in speech and wits, poor fellow.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: He canna talk, say you? Bid him come in.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.stage: [Opening the door.]
sp.p: Come you in and get a taste o' the fire.
sp.stage: [The pedlar enters with his tray of trifles and goes to the hearth. He is brute-like in his stolidity.]

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAESPEARE
sp.p: Sit you down, good man. [He shakes his head.] Well, if you canna, let us see if you've aught we would buy. [She and WILL look at the tray.] I'd like to get a bit o' something for your father, laddie.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: There seems naught for men but masks, and father's face is too good to cover.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: I'll get him a kerchief. That's rare enough to be treat. How much, Pedlar?
sp.stage: [He make signs with his fingers.]

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Here is a string o' blue beads--a young maid's rosary. Put it 'round your neck, Betsy. [To his mother.] I'll buy it out of the New Year's coin father gave me.
sp.stage: [PEDLAR again tells the price by signs.]

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: For me? O Will! Thanky! I be mortal glad you dinna get me needles, or aught that's useful. An' I be glad too, I 'aven't a Adam's apple, or it wotna fit. Doant I look brave?

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: That you do. I'll get the money for you, Pedlar.
sp.stage: [Exit MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE door, left. WILL goes toward rear to count out the pedlar's pay. BETSY is engaged with her new treasure. The pedlar empties the remander of the apples and cakes into a bag at his side. Enter MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE.]

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.stage: [As she and WILL pay the pedlar.]
sp.p: Eat some cakes afore you go out into the night. [Sees the empty dish.] What's happed to the cakes? They were in the dish but a moment since! There may be more.
sp.stage: [Goes to table at rear. WILL, stirs fire. The pedlar, fearing detection, empties the cakes back into the dish. WILL turns.]

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Mother, the cakes have leaped into the dish. They must be full o' yeast to rise and fall so lightly. [Smiling.] Help yourself, Pedlar. As to apples, I'd ofer you some but more might give you a touch o' the colic.
sp.stage: PEDLAR goes to the door.]

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Come you again, Master Pedlar.
sp.stage: [He nods sullenly. Exit PEDLAR.]

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: There be a man you couldna find any stories in. He be cold an' muddy as eel.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: O Betsy! will you never see? I could light his eyes, loose his tongue--yea, wake him from the dead. 'Tis the miracle that tugs at me night and day.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: I'd see if I could, Will. Anyways I know beads when I see 'em. We mun go now. Dickums relished the pikelets an' apples right well, an' me too, missus.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Wrap you up, lassie.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: My beads'll keep me warm.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I'll see you home.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: Nay, Will. I be goin' to stop at the Pringles 'round the corner. God buy ye.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Come again, Betsy girl, you and your Dickums.
sp.stage: [Exeunt BETSY and DICKUMS. MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE and WILL put away the ironing and carry the two ables from the front to the rear, left.]

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Mother, instead of going a-merry-making tonight with the lads, I would ask something else of you.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Speak out, laddie. When have I found it in my heart to deny you aught I could grant?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Let me for this night stay up as long as I would.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKSPEARE
sp.p: And not go out with the lads on New Year's Eve? Marry come up! 'tis a right droll wish.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: You know my Christmas book that Sir Thomas gave me at Grammar School.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEAR
sp.p: Thomas Hunt, God speed him!--not Thomas Lucy.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p:
Methinks Hunt is short for goodness and Lucy
short for Lucifer. Besides, Thomas Hunt doth spell Thomas with one S and Thomas Lucy perforce must use two!

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Fie, lad! see that your wrongs make not your tongue over sharp. But what o' the book your master gave you?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I would sit up this night, burn as many candles as I choose, and read to my soul's contentment.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: I see no reason why you shouldna. Your father is away, Gilbert and Joan are at our cousin's till the morrow, and the wee nna and Richard sound asleep this long while. Stay you up, an you wish. Help me with the churn, laddie. [They bring it forward and place it at center, left.] Now is it ready for the morrow. 'Tis fine sport coaxing cream to change itself to butter.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.stage: [Peeping insde the churn.]
sp.p: 'Twould be a bonnie hiding place for merry-minded goblins! Oh, Mother, I shall have a brave evening with the fairies. Ovid has made me friends with Titania, and the book I would read is full o' the doings o' the magic people. There is a king called Oberon and tonight all of us will gallop away on a slant o' silvery moonshine.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Bless you, my lad. Would I could join you in your fairy caperings.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: See the kettle! 'Tis a cauldron to breed witches and their tailless kind.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: Your mind is a busy cauldron but it breeds more than witches.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.stage: [Going to the window.]
sp.p: We shall hve a moon tonight. There is something about moonlight that searches out every nook and corner of me and drenches me with music. Some day--oh, Mother, I have a desire so tall that it tucks its head into the very lap of heaven.

sp.speaker: MISTRESS SHAKESPEARE
sp.p: I know it, laddie. You are all a-shimmer with lovely fancies. God shield you, my dearest.
sp.stage: [She kisses WILL and leaves through door, left. WILL takes the book out of his doublet and with a sigh of joyousness throws himself before the fire, a candle near his open page.]

div2.head: ACT I
div2.stage: The curtain reascends immediately on a darkened stage. RUSTICS are heard singing in the distance, their song growing clearer as they pass the Shakespeare home, and again becoming fainter as they move on. A half-moon rises and shines through the window.

sp.speaker: RUSTICS
sp.stage: [Singing.]

lg.l: Here we come on New Year's Day
Come ye out and fill ye up,
Take a whiff and drink a sup--
We would give to each of you
Thank your God for what you've got,
Thank your God for what you've not,
Thank Him for the wassail pot
On New Year's in the morning.

div2.stage:
[The clock strikes twelve. The chimnes of Stratford ring out. Tiny lights flush, coming from FIREFLY hiding near the fire-
place, COWSLIP under the table, WASP behind the churn, and PEPPER-CORN in the shadow of a chair. The lid of the settle is raised and a fifth light appears.]

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.stage: [Within the settle.]
sp.p: Whist!
sp.stage: [In a tinkling he and his PUCKS fly out of hiding. ROBIN standing in the path of the moon's rays, holds aloft his sprak of light.]

lg.l: Drive away the bat of night.

sp.stage: [The gloom lifts and they join and caper in a dance, with leap-frog pranks and elfin riot.]

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Attention, sprites!
sp.stage: [The PUCKS line up.]

sp.speaker: PUCKS
sp.p: Ready!

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: There is heavy business on foot.

sp.speaker: PUCKS
sp.stage: [Hopping, each with hand on foot.]
sp.p: Ouch!

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: What ails you?

sp.speaker: COWSLIP
sp.p: Please, Robin, as you said there is heavy business on foot, my toes did hurt as if a cask had rolled upon them.

sp.speaker: WASP
sp.p: My toes ache not, but my instep feels as 'twere on fire.

sp.speaker: FIREFLY
sp.p: 'Tis not my toes nor my instep, oh Robin-come-bobbin', 'tis my heel. I vow 'tis rosy with pain.

sp.speaker: PEPPER-CORN
sp.p: You are lucky 'tis but your instep, toe and heel. I have a monstrous prickling from ankle to thigh bone.

sp.speaker: PUCKS
sp.stage: [in rapid succession.]
sp.p: My toes!
My instep!
My heel!
My ankle and thigh bone!

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.stage: [Disdainfully.]
sp.p: An you had your deserts your merrybones would be snapped like that! Let me know when you are ready to hearken to reason.

sp.speaker: PUCKS
sp.stage: [Lining up sedatedly.]
sp.p: We are ready.

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: I am come on a quest from Oberon. Our King and Queen have had a monstrous falling out.

sp.speaker: COWSLIP
sp.p: Already have the winds blown the rumor to our ears.
sp.stage: [The PUCKS shake their heads gravely.]

sp.speaker: WASP
sp.p: Has it not to do with a babe?

sp.speaker: FIREFLY
sp.p: A little Indian boy?

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Yea; the son of Titania's friend who dwelt in the land of lotus blossoms and savory sandalwood. When she, being mortal, died, Titania brought home the babe.

sp.speaker: PEPPER-CORN
sp.p: 'Tis said he is bronze of color.

sp.speaker: COWSLIP
sp.p: And that our Queen dotes on him.

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Oberon wishes the changeling for his own--to be reared as his henchman. The Queen refuses to yield him the child, which doth set the King at loggerheads with her.

sp.speaker: PEPPER-CORN
sp.p: Marry come up! 'tis a pretty pother.

sp.speaker: FIREFLY
sp.p: What have you to do with their tempest, Robin?

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: I am to get the babe and give him into Oberon's keeping.

sp.speaker: PUCKS
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: The Witch of Wimble is to place him in my hands.

sp.speaker: WASP
sp.p: The Witch of Wimble is a brewer of mischief.

sp.speaker: COWSLIP
sp.p: And likes to stick her long gaunt finger into other people's pies.

sp.speaker: PEPPER-CORN
sp.p: She drives a hard bargain.

sp.speaker: FIREFLY
sp.p: How came she to do aught for you?

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p:
Beshrew me, if I be not a wondrous sharp fellow!
I am to give the Wimble Witch a paring from the Duchess of Bannister's finger nail in exchange for the Indian boy. 'Tis the hour for the signal.
sp.stage: [He goes to the fireplace and raps on the pot three times.]
[There is a puff of red smoke and the WIMBLE WITCH emerges, a baby hanging over her shoulder. She wears a scraggly beard and has a long right forefinger.]

sp.speaker: WITCH

lg.l: Hoot! hoot! thou owl of night.

sp.stage: [Sound of winds.]

lg.l: Dim the moon in thy light.

sp.stage: The light lowers.]
sp.p: Bah! I like not such giddy brightness. Well, well, Robin Goodfellow! have you brought me the paring?

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Ay, Goody.

sp.speaker: WITCH
sp.p: Give it hither.

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Give me first the babe.

sp.speaker: WITCH
sp.p: Not till I lay hands on your paring.

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: I must have the babe before I gve it you.

sp.speaker: WITCH
sp.p: Two rouges drive a slow bargain.

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Speak for yourself, an you will, but I am no rogue. My name belies it--Goodfellow.

sp.speaker: WITCH
sp.p: Ay, but what o' your name Robin? Is not he that's robin' a robber?

sp.speaker: COWSLIP
sp.p: Give me the babe, Goody, and, Robin, give you the paring to Firefly. When I say the word, we shall see that each gets his own.

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Are you of a mind to it?

sp.speaker: WITCH
sp.p: Yea, 'twere best.
sp.stage: [She tosses the baby to COWSLIP and ROBIN gives the paring to FIREFLY.]

sp.speaker: COWSLIP
sp.stage: [ROBIN joyously receives the baby handling it awkwardly and the WITCH clutches the paring.]

sp.speaker: WITCH
sp.p: At last! Now will the upstart Duchess do my bidding.

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: What's to do with 'em?

sp.speaker: WITCH
sp.p: With what?

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Babes.

sp.speaker: PUCKS
sp.p: Yea, what's to do with 'em?

sp.speaker: WITCH
sp.p: Milk! Milk! Milk! Plenty o' milk! Fill 'em full o' milk. But mind your own brat. I have my precious paring.
sp.stage: [The WITCH dances, then disappears within the fireplace.]

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Good riddance! Let us see our noses; this witch-light pleases not my fancy.

lg.l: Drive away the bat of night.

sp.stage: [The room lights. The baby cries.]
sp.p: Deuce take it! 'tis a nuisance.

sp.speaker: FIREFLY
sp.p: Milk! plenty o' milk!

sp.speaker: WASP
sp.p: The Wimble Witch said so!

sp.speaker: PEPPER-CORN
sp.p: Ay, but where's it to be found?

sp.speaker: COWSLIP
sp.p: The churn!

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Marry, you are right. [He tosses the cryng baby into the churn, upight. There is a lusty yell.] Verily,'tis a milk-curdling sound! [Another cry, then silence.] Yea, drink your fill, inchling! Lap up the cream with your little pink tongue. Who says it is difficult to care for babes? Mayhap bronze-face will now turn whey-face.

sp.speaker: COWSLIP
sp.p: Hist! a step.

div2.stage: [They disappear within their former retreats. There is a knock. Enter WILL, left, dressed as in the Prologue. He goes to door rear, and opens it. The threshold is empty for a moment until BETSY, in the costume of a picture-book shepherdess, jumps out of hiding.]

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.stage: [Suddenly, as she comes into view.]
sp.p: Boo!
sp.stage: [She enters smiling.]

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: 'Tis plain to see, Betsy, you're not too timid to say Boo! to a goose.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: It is not geese I fear--'tis wolves. But my flock is safe sheltered, even to the blackest sheep o' them all.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Had I your crook, faith, I'd use it to drive into the fold the solemn-souled folk o' Stratford.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: They who count it a sin to smile--like Sullen Jim, the tinker.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Ay, his face is so long his chin is red and calloused where he hath tripped on it. But smile or scowl, 'tis a work-a-day world and I must try my hand at churning--yet who would say that changing rivers o' cream into mountains o' butter be not magic? [He tries to work the dasher.] What ails it?

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: Here! get you aside. 'Tis a maid's work, not a man's.
sp.stage: [The dasher will not work, and try as she will, BETSY cannot churn.]
sp.p: A plague on the thing! 'Tis bootless churning. [There is a loud wail.] It seems to come from here. [Points in alarm at the churn.]

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I'll look within.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: Are you not fearful?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: 'Tis a maid's part to churn; a man's not to be afraid.
sp.stage: [Goes to churn and pulls out the baby.]

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: A babe!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Faith, a very milksop!
sp.stage: [ROBIN and the PUCKS leap out and circle around the children.]

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.stage: [Good humoredly.]
sp.p: You are bedlam let loose! Cease your hubbub and tell us who you are.

sp.speaker: ROBIN and the PUCKS
sp.stage: [in rapid succession, bowing.]
sp.p: Robin Goodfellow.
Cowslip.
Firefy.
Wasp.
Pepper-corn.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Well met, good people. [ROBIN stands on his head.] You silly goblin--standing on your north when you should be walking on your south! Pray tell us how babe and butter got so strangely mixed.

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.stage: [Scrambling to his feet and seizing the baby.]
sp.p: He is my charge.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: For shame! handling him like meal sack. You are as cIumsy as if you came from Bergamo. [She stamps her foot.] Give him to me, you saucy manikin. [She takes the baby and cuddles him.] My poor lamb! my wee nestling!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: How came you by the babe?

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: I am its guardian. The Wimble Witch seized him from Titania and placed him in my hands. I am to give him into the keeping of Oberon who fancies him for his own.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: Is not Titania his mother?

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: His foster-mother.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: Then why does she yield him, even to Oberon, her lord?

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Pouf! She has naught to say about it. The Witch and I saw to that.
sp.stage: [The PUCKS play leap-frog and cut up antics.]

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.stage: [Aside to BETSY.]
sp.p: That wight has stolen the babe.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: Poor Titania!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Let us restore the boy to her.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: A right sound thought. We'll do it. But how get away?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Send Robin and his crew on an errand. Ho, Robin! ho, Pucks!

sp.speaker: ROBIN and the PUCKS
sp.p: Ay, ay, sir.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p:
How do you expect this babe to drink milk and get
his rightful nourishment unless he take it from a bottle?

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.stage: [Scratching his head.]
sp.p: Do babes take milk out o' bottles?

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: Of course, addlepate.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: A fine guardian you, to give milk to your babe by throwing him into a churn!

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: It has a foolish sound. Marry, sir, what mortal fools we fairies be!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Hie you hence and bring back a nursing bottle, and let not Time, the old nag, go limping with you. Ride him hard and dig in the spurs.

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Up, boys, away! But where, good sir, may the magic bottles be found?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: At the apothecary's, slim-wit!

sp.speaker: COWSLIP
sp.p: His shop is but two hoots and a hurdle from the Golden Lion.

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Forward.
sp.stage: [Exeunt PUCKS.]

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Now must we ride Time harder than I did counsel Robin.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: West to Sanctus, thence south to the Brake.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: Ay, a Fairy Queen should not be far from the Brake.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Should I not have a staff, or wherewithal to protect you and the babe?

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: That you should, Will.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I would I had a sword. I know!--the huge knife with which mother cuts the loaf.
sp.stage: [Runs to table and gives a cry.]

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: What is it, Will?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Behold the changeling! The bread knife has turned sword. [He dislays the sword, then proudly claps it to his side. He feels his chin.] Had I but a beard! But come! lean seconds make fat minutes.
sp.stage: [Exeunt WILL, BETSY and the INDIAN BOY, leaving the door open. There is a puff of red smoke in the fireplace and the WITCH comes forth.]

sp.speaker: WITCH
sp.p: West to Sanctus, thence south to the Brake. Ha! 'tis time the Wimble Witch stirred puddings with her finger. [Stirs ith her forefinger.] I'll have my way in this or may I lose my bonnie beard. [Rush of winds.] Ay, there be forces still at work for the Witch of Wimble.
sp.stage: [Exit WITCH through fireplace.]

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.stage: [The PEDLAR, off stage.]

lg.l: Come buy of Filch, the Pedlar

sp.stage: [He appears in the open doorway, the dum and stolid pedlar of the Prologue awakened to a rollicking alertness. A large, open sack is strapped to is shoulder. He looks around the room with a merry glance, goes to the table, left, slyly takes up a candlestick, starts to put it into his sack, then with a shrug replaces it on the table. He goes off calling lustily.]

lg.l: Come buy of Filch, the Pedlar.

sp.stage: [This far-off tinkling of bells. It grows nearer. TITANIA and her train enter eagerly and peer in out of corners.]

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: O Chalice! Cadence! Dulcet! Melody! He is not here--of a truth he is not here!

sp.speaker: CHALICE
sp.p: Are you sure the Bullfinch sent you hither?

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: Yea, Chalice, he said here, in this very room. And not alone the Bullfinch saw Robin with the babe, but the Hornéd Owl who lives in the Brake. They peeped through the window.

sp.speaker: MELODY
sp.p: May Melody turn Discord if Robin be not made to smart for crossing you.

sp.speaker: CADENCE
sp.p: And such a darling babe, with his pretty bronze skin and his big brown eyes!

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: I think--yea, I am certain--my heart is breaking.

sp.speaker: FAIRIES
sp.p: Heart!

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: Said I heart? Well, verily, by the threefold Diana, I believe I am growing one.

sp.speaker: CHALICE
sp.p: Why think you that?

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.stage: [Folding her hands over her heart.]
sp.p: Ihave a sad feeling here.

sp.speaker: MELODY
sp.p: 'Tis a sorry business.

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.stage: [Reaching out her hands on both sides.]
sp.p: And as if the world were a vastly bigger place than it is, and I were lost in it.

sp.speaker: DULCET
sp.p: I've never felt like that--have you, Cadence?

sp.speaker: CADENCE
sp.p: Nay, I have never felt sad or lost.

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: O, Dulcet, mine eyes!

sp.speaker: DUCET
sp.p: Your eyes, sweet mistress?

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: Something like dew escapeth them.

sp.speaker: DULCET
sp.stage: (Drying them with a bit of her frock.)
sp.p: I've not seen the like before.

sp.speaker: CHALICE
sp.p: You forget. When the little gooseherd was forsaken by her lover, do you not remember how dew ran down her cheeks?

sp.speaker: DULCET
sp.p: And sparkled in the moonlight?

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: I remember. 'Twas said those were tears.

sp.speaker: CADENCE
sp.p: Then that dew--oh, that dew from your eyes is--

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: Tears. These must be tears. Now do I know I am growing a heart.

sp.speaker: MELODY
sp.p: What can a fairy do with a heart?

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: T'would be monstrous useful with a babe.
sp.stage: [Enter ROBIN and his fellows lugging a large stone jug.]

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Here is the nursing bottle. Filch, the Pedlar from whom I bought it, says 'tis the only one in town.

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: Robin!
sp.stage: [ROBIN and the PUCKS bow and scrape.]

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Celestial Titania--

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: Where is my babe?

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Is he not here? Then that's what I would know,--where is he?

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: Know you not, of a truth?

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Nay, he was here when I started for the bottle. Do I speak true?

sp.speaker: PUCKS
sp.p: He speaks true.

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Mayhap he is in the churn. [Looks within.] Butter! 'Tis full of butter! The babe hath churned it by his frisky gambolings.

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: What shall we do? O Robin! I could find it in this new heart to forgive you, would you do your best to find him. I would rather Oberon had him than he should be lost.

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: 'Tis a big world.

sp.speaker: CADENCE
sp.p: For a new babe.

sp.speaker: CHALICE
sp.p: Ay, to be lost in.

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: We will seek him high and low--will we not, lads?

sp.speaker: PUCKS
sp.p: Ay, ay, sir!

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: And we will search the green earth till we wear it brown with our footfalls ere we forsake our quest--is it not so, Fairies?

sp.speaker: FAIRIES
sp.p: As true as true.

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Which way shall we go?

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: I have a fancy to seek him in the Brake. Let us first to the south, then west to the Brake.

sp.speaker: WITCH
sp.stage: [Appearing in a puff of red snoke from the fireplace.]
sp.p: Nay, you are wrong. I would do you a service. The lad, Will, and the wench have taken the babe and plan to sell him to a childless prince.

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: Tailless rat! How dare I believe you?

sp.speaker: WITCH
sp.p: By my bonnie beard, I speak true.

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: Then which way went they?

sp.speaker: WITCH
sp.p: I heard them say, "First east, then north."

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: My thanks, dame. Fairies, hence!

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Forward, lads!

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.stage: (As her Fairies and the PUCKS stream out into the night.]

lg.l: Be ye valiant, be ye fleet;
Bring ye tokens of my boy.

sp.stage: [Exit TITANIA.]

sp.speaker: WITCH

lg.l: Hoot! hoot! thou owl of night.

sp.stage: [Sound of winds.]

lg.l: Dim the moon in thy flight.

sp.stage: [The light lessens.]
sp.p: Ay, silly-pates, look your fill Who says this finger has not the gift of stirring other people's puddings?

lg.l: Stir and linger, stir and linger,
Poke and pry, thou busy finger.

sp.stage: [The cock crows. The WITCH rushes to the fireplace. There is a puff of red smoke and she disappears. The cock crows again.]

div2.head: ACT II
div2.stage: SCENE: A clearing in the Forest of Arden. It is the afternoon of May-day. A grassy knoll is near the right front. Trees and bushes circle the clearing. Country folk move back and forth, bubbling with pleasure in the day and scene.

FILCH has a tray suspended from his neck on which are masks, trinkets, ballads rolled and tied with ribbons, and an open sack, as in Act I. From time to time he deftly removes a purse or trifle from one of the crowd. He is industriously hawking his wares.

lg.l: Come ye one and come ye many,
Bits and bobs for half a penny,
And if you would spend a shilling
Take my trayful, an you're willing.
Fortunes by the hour I'll tell you,
Ballads by the yard I'll sell you.
Name, that I may do the dishing.
Come you sweet, and pay so little
Come you sour and full o' trouble
Filch will joy to charge you double.

sp.speaker: LASS
sp.p: Please, Master Filch, read my fortune.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: Your fortune is plain in your face--and yet, God wot, 'tis not a plain face.

sp.speaker: LASS
sp.p: What read ye there?

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: A marvel of nature: that cherries and tulips are one and the same, and being plucked should bring a high market price.
sp.stage: [There is a laugh and the lass is discomfited.]

sp.speaker: LASS
sp.p: You'll get na pay for that!

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: I had hopes that in payment you would shake down just one cherry for me.
sp.stage: [The crowd guffaws. A second lass puts forth her hand.]

sp.speaker: SECOND LASS
sp.p: Prithee, look at that, Master Pedlar.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: A smooth dial; a white dial. You would know what o'clock by it? It says your sun is well up in the heavens and has cast no shadows for you.

sp.speaker: SECOND LASS
sp.p: But, good Master Pedlar, donna you see any--lads?

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: Lads? Nay.

sp.speaker: SECOND LASS
sp.stage: [Pouting.]
sp.p: I donna believe you.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: Lads, nay, but lad--yea! There is one lad so much at home he has driven off all t'others. He looks as if he were come to stay.

sp.speaker: BUMPKN
sp.stage: [Elbowing up and taking the lass by the arm.]
sp.p: May I eat naught but dunch-dumplings, Pedlar, if 'tisna true. Gi' me a smudge, lass, an' say the word.
sp.stage: [She runs into the crowd, he pursuing.]

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.stage: [Holding up a small bottle.]
sp.p: Here be May-day dew that I bottled at dawn. 'Twill make the complexion as clear as the bells o' Trinity steeple. Only a few bottles left. [Aside, with a wink.] Dipped fresh from the Avon, within the hour!
sp.stage: [A bumpkin enters on a run, chased by two or three laughing lasses. He wears a devil's mask, with horns, and ducks in and out of the crowd until captured. They lead him forward.]

sp.speaker: ONE OF THE LASSES
sp.p:
Master Pedlar, the Old Harry's horns be horns o'
plenty and he wishes to pour some o' your bauble on us.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: Good devil! Generous devil! They will make o' you afore long a smug, respectable devil. [The girls busily select their gewgaws from FILCH'S tray.] Here be straws, oaten straws--the very straws themselves--with which Cupid--the sly-boots!--tickled the chin of his lady love. Come, worthies, and buy. [Aside.] Fresh from Farmer Goodman's haystack!

sp.speaker: YOUTH
sp.p: Whut good be they to a body?

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: What good, ye ask? Why, just as Cupid tickled the chin of his wench and caused her to snigger, so may ye try it on the chin o' your lass and make her to smile on you. Na smile, na pay.

sp.speaker: YOUTH
sp.p: That do be worth tryin'. Gi' me mortal fine one.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: Here 'tis--a tawny, oaten straw, Cupid's own.
sp.stage: [YOUTH takes it and tickles the chin of a lass. She gigges riotously. The youth claps his knee with delight and pays FILCH. Enter WILL and BETSY, the latter carrying the INDIAN BOY.]

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.stage: [To Will.]
sp.p: Mayhap someone here can tell us.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.stage: [To a by stander.]
sp.p: Good morrow, Sir. Can you tell us where dwells Titania, the Queen?

sp.speaker: BYSTANDER
sp.p: Queen o' what?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: The Fairies.

sp.speaker: BYSTANDER
sp.p: Na, I ken naught o' the Queen o' the Fairies.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.stage: [Scenting customers.]
sp.p: Young sir, I see by your sword and babe you are both a man of action and a man of family.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I am neither, wag, as you know.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: You have me hipped. Command me.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: We seek a Queen called Titania. Know you where she may be found?

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p:
Alack, young sir, your Queen I know not. But have
you heard that our good Queen Bess is to witness the morris-dancers and the May-pole?

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: The Queen, Will? Shall we see the Queen?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Yea, we shall stay. Perchance she may aid us.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: Ho, little lamb! You shall see our Queen with your very own peepers.
sp.stage: [FILCH has removed WILL'S purse which hung at his side. The baby cries and FILCH is all genial solicitude. He shakes a dried gourd enticingly.]

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: Lookee, you lusty recklin. Listen to the music. [The cries cease.] He has marvelous ear for music, good sir. You should buy this for him.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Faith, I'll do it. [Misses his pouch.] Soul and body o' me! My purse has been taken.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: Surely, you mistake.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Certes, 'tis gone. And my new mill-sixpence that I did hold for a wishing-piece!

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: Alackaday! What scape-gallows could ha' done this fell thing?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Now I cannot buy the babe his bauble.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: 'Tis top-full sorry business. Filch would ever do a good turn an he could. Make for me a ballad or couplet or what-not, in payment for this monstrous fine charmer, and you shall keep it for your bronzy brat.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Agreed, Master Pedlar. I'll whip up my muse.

lg.l: Filch thou art and Filch thou'lt be,
Too much Filch by half for me.
Filch by name and Filch by trade,
Filch, thy fortune's good as made,
For thou'lt mount to higher things--
E'en to Tyburn spread thy wings.
Thou cant steal a breath of air.

sp.stage: [There is a round of laughter in which FILCH is foremost.]

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p:
Take the gourd, boy. May all my teeth be strung on lute strings and hung in the Old Harry's barber
shop, if you have not earned it! Marry, what have we here? [Stoops.] Your purse!
sp.stage:
[Hands it to WILL.
Lutes and singing are heard. A lad runs in breathlessly from the right.]

sp.speaker: LAD
sp.p: Make way! Make way! Our Queen be acomin'! Our Queen be a-comin'!
sp.stage: [A wave of eagerness stirs the crowd, and it falls back, though inclining expecantly toward the approaching company. The strumming and singing have grown louder and the MINSTRELS stroll in, followed by QUEEN ELIZABETH (whose costume is topped by a crown), a LADY-IN-WAITING, and SIR THOMAS LUCY.]

sp.speaker: THE MINSTRELS
sp.stage: [Singing.]

lg.l: Who would not sing on May-day,
Who would not sing on May-day
Who would not dance on May-day,
Who would not dance on May-day

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.stage: [Sinking upon the knoll.]
sp.p: Cease your noise, madcaps. You will set me to dancing ere I know it.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: Come, lads and lasses! Swell your girths, and give a cheer for our good Queen Bess.
sp.stage: [They cheer stoutly.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: My thanks, loyal subjects. The ship of state need never be becalmed, if the bellows of England blow so gustily.

sp.speaker: LADY-IN-WAITING
sp.p: This seems a brave adventure.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Tis at least a time-whiler.
sp.stage: [FILCH puts a cap over his doubled fist, which he has dotted with two black spots for eyes and, making his fingers move as if they were a mouth, speaks in a falsetto.]

lg.l: Come buy of Filch, the Pedlar.
He'll sell you aught from brats to brains;
He'll laugh at you for all your pains;

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: I wager yon fellow is as full of quips and quillets as the sea of brine. Ho, Pedlar! [FILCH appoaches and bows.] For how long has peddling been your profession?

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: Beshrew my heart, Majesty, if peddling be my profession; 'tis but my recreation.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Indeed, merry lob! What call you your profession?

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: An it please you, I am a skilled arithmetician; quick at subtraction [removing a ribbon from a nearby lass], able in addition [adding the ribbon to his sack], keen at multiplication [taking a purse with one hand and a fan from the LADY-IN-WAITING with the other], and celebrated in division. [Aside.] Long division for Filch and short division for t'others.

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.p: Arithmetics is a cold business--as hard as iron.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: Or steel!

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: You should find a softer one.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: Already have I done so.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: How, fellow?

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: I am an artist. I draw from life.
sp.stage: [Removes a handkerchief from SIR THOMAS'S sleeve.]

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Mayhap if your artist skill match your wit I shall give you a pose.

sp.speaker: FILCH
THE QUEEN
sp.p: Heigh ho, boiled brain! Your nonsense threats my poise, but the pose is yours.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: God mend me! My pose is but your poise blinded.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Unriddle your speech.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: What is pose but poise with its eye out?

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Knave, you shall not have my pose in spectacles.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: Your beauteous pose shall be of itself the spectacle.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Fie upon you! [Sound of bugles.] The dancers!

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: The dancers! Stand back, you gapes, if you would not get your toes cracked.
sp.stage: [The bugles draw nearer. Enter FRIAR TUCK with solemn mien, bearing a heavy staff. The crowd cheers. He gravely makes the circuit of the clearing and drops his staff upon some obtruding toes. The victim shrieks.]

sp.speaker: FRIAR TUCK
sp.p:
Think not of self. Count thy beads and repent thee of thy folly. [The crowd heer and laughs. The FRIAR drops his staff on SIR TOMAS'S feet, which causes him
to leap in pained surprise.] Back! turn thee back while yet there be time. Thy feet, dancing as on a gridiron, have strayed from out the straight and narrow path. Say a pater-noster and 'ware thee o' purgatory.
sp.stage: [The crowd roars.]

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Already you have a touch of purgatorial fires in your toes, eh, Lucy?
sp.stage: [FRIAR TUCK stands aside and the bugles again sound. Enter ROBIN HOOD and the other morris-dancers, the HOBBY HORSE and the DRAGON bringing up the rear. They dance.
At the conclusion of the dance there is cheering, and the QUEEN sends a purse to ROBIN HOOD.

Exeunt dancers to the sound of bugle, pipe, and bell. The crowd follows with the exception of the QUEEN, WILL, BETSY, the INDIAN BOY, SIR THOMAS, the LADY-IN-WAITING, FILCH, and the MINSTRELS. WILL and BETSY await an opportunity to approach the QUEEN. FILCH retires up stage to count his money and look over his wares.]

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: I have been vastly diverted. [To SIR THOMAS.] Sir Long Face, why do you not seek to amuse me?

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: I, your Majesty?

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Yea, you, my majesty! Your visage hath been washed in vinegar.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: You misjudge me. I can be as rompish as a babe. [Looks around.] Ho, Pedlar!

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: O Sir, most worthy Sir, here am I, Sir!

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Give me your drollest mask.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.stage: [Rummaging in his sack and briging forth an ass's head.]
sp.p: This it is, your worthiness. [Aside.] 'Tis his twin brother.
sp.stage: [SIR THOMAS claps on the head, tossing FILCH a coin which he catches, bites, spits upon, rubs, and thrusts into his money bag. SIR THOMAS makes his courtliest bow to the QUEEN.]

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Speak, I bray you; I have ears for your slightest word.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: You graven image! Now are you in truth in royal favor. Verily, two heads are better than one, thoug one is--Sir Thomas's!
sp.stage: [WILL and BETSY, with the baby, come forward.]

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: An it please you, gracious Queen,--

sp.speaker: LADY-IN-WAITING
sp.p: Stand you back, chuff. Would you address her Majesty without permission?

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: I am inclined to yeaward. Bid them approach. Why, Sir Thomas! May I take eggs for money if this lad be not your youthful poacher.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: But I did not poach, your Majesty.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: What matters it, so long as you were forgiven?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: It matters much to me.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Marry, the March-cluck hath an ostrich conscience. How you did manage to hatch that giant bird out of your tiny shell, I wot not. Beware lest it swallow you whole.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Laugh, an you will, at my expense. I can afford to pay.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Would that you were my treasurer. Now, chick, what wish you of your Queen?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: May it please your Majesty to help us restore this babe to his foster-mother.
sp.stage: [BETSY, with a cursy, holds forth the baby.]

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: His foster-mother? Who is she?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: A Queen.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: A Queen, say ye?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: A most beauteous Queen.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.stage: [Her glance cooling.]
sp.p: Indeed! She must be fair.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: 'Tis said she hath the radiancy o' dawn and the grace o' twilight.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Who is your paragon,--Venus?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: She is called Titania and is Queen of all the Fairies.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: We know naught of your Titania. [To SIR THOMAS.] What think you, Lucy--this lad hath stolen from your park; why not from the cradle?

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: 'Tis most likely, I should say.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Ass, look not so serious. [To her LADY-IN-WAITING.] Doth it not seem probable the boy hath stolen the babe?

sp.speaker: LADY-IN-WAITING
sp.p: Certes, I vow you are right. Both the wench and lad have a guilty look. And yet, they are seeking to restore the babe, said they not?

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Ay--they're doubtless tired o' their burden and now would rid themselves of it. Ho, Pedlar!--eke artist--eke arithmetician.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: Thrice at your service; and I come speedily, for my peddling feet hope to run down a sale, my artistical feet draw me with ease, and my arithmetical feet bear me quickest of all because o' their numbers.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Then bid your three-fold feet bear you featlier than ever. I would have them fetch constable.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: Feet, do hear your Queen and Master? Majesty, they say every toe has a quadruple joint and that in each heel have the wings of Mercury feathered.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Away, Chatterbox! Your tongue has more joints than all your toes together. [Exit FILCH on a run. WILL and BETSY move away.] Stop, boy. A constable will take you and your babe in charge until your beauteous Titania has been found.
sp.stage: [SIR THOMAS vainly endeavors to remove his mask-head.]

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Will someone give me aid? I tire o' this folly.
sp.stage: [The MINSTRELS go to his assistance, but the head will not come off. WILL and BETSY have moved near SIR THOMAS. Enter FILCH and the CONSTABLE.]

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: Here comes the law's staunch pillar, Majesty.
sp.stage: [The CONSTABLE bows and scrapes, and scrapes and bows, pulling his forelock industriously.]

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Do not uproot your forelock, Master Constable, else what would be left with which to salute your Queen?
sp.stage: [The CONSTABLE is stupefied with confusion.]

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.stage: To CONSTABLE in whisper.]
sp.p: You still could scratch your head.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.stage: Brightening, and re-commencing his bows and scrapes.]
sp.p: Ah-yea, Queen, I cud scrattle m' yed.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Stand on your yed, mon, an it please you--but, marry, come up! what means this tangle?
sp.stage: [SIR THOMAS has been trying with mounting energy to remove the mask, and the MINSTRELS are tugging with might and main.]

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Help! Deuce take the thing!

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Lucy, I am your debtor. Never saw I more pleasing sight for laughter.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Get me out o' this.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: May I be carbonadoed if 'tis not a waggish spectacle. Will 't not come off?
sp.stage: [FILCH takes the baby from the arms of BETSY, who is absorbed in the struggle, and drops him into the sack.]

sp.speaker: ONE OF THE MINSTRELS
sp.p: 'Tis held by a thousand furies.

sp.speaker: ANOTHER MINSTREL
sp.p: 'Twill not budge.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: I am dying of shame. Let me escape the sight of men.
sp.stage: [He runs off.]

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Pshaw! the diverting play is over.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: It speaks well for the lasting quality o' my wares.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Hither, fellow! You went on our mission so featly we would give you our purse for your pains and entertainment.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: Not your purse, Majesty, O most sweet, sweet Majesty. I cannot take your purse.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Then name your own reward.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p:
I will take but one golden crown. And I will not
spend it. I will keep it to bear you in mind. One golden crown.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Take it, fellow, and welcome.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.stage: [Pointing forwards. All looking expectantly.]
sp.p: See yonder!
sp.stage: [He removes the crown from the QUEEN'S head and drops it into his sack.]

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: What mean you?

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: Your pardon, Majesty, most, most sweet Majesty, but mine eyes, I fear, did play me tricks. Methought a sparrow was robbing a hawk's nest.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Let us to business. Master Constable, take into custody this babe and the lad and lass who stole it.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.stage: [Running forward, her arms a outstretched.]
sp.p: Gone! the babe is gone!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: The bronze nestling out of its cage! But it could not fly far.
sp.stage: [FILCH slips off, right.]

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Impossible! Does neither of you know what has happed to the poor babe? Have you not hidden him?

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Have search made, if you think it likely--in the crotch of yon tree--in a last year's acorn cup--in a mary-bud's pocket o' gold. There are a score o' places in which babes may be tucked away--out of sight o' the blind.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: You prate saucily. Constable, let these children see the lining of the Town Cage till they confess their misdeeds. [The CONSTABLE scratches his head.] Ay, scrattle your yed, mon. All your wits are on the outside of it.
sp.stage: [Raises hands to her head. Gives a cry and leaps to her feet.]

sp.speaker: LADY-IN-WAITING
sp.p: Sweet Queen, what ails you?

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: My crown!

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Your crown!

sp.speaker: LADY-IN-WAITING
sp.p: Who could have taken it?

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p: The gentleman Ass.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Body o' me, nay. Sir Thomas hath not the imagination.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.stage: [Banging his fist smartly on his hand.]
sp.p: The Pedlar! Filch!

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Boy, you have said. He hath the wit and methinks he hath the roguery.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: He went southward but a moment since.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Enough. My crown!

sp.speaker: WILL and BETSY
sp.p: The babe!
sp.stage: [The MINSTRELS, followed by WILL, BETSY, the CONSTABLE, the LADY-IN-WAITING and the QUEEN rush off stage shouting variously, "The crown!" "The babe!"]

div2.head: ACT III
div2.stage: SCENE: The Forest of Arden in the moonlight.
SIR THOMAS is in the center of the clearing making fantastic and despairing efforts to remove the ass-head.
Fairy bells tinkle. Enter TITANIA and her train. Seeing SIR THOMAS they burst into peals of mirth.

sp.speaker: FAIRIES
sp.stage: [They circle round him in a dance.]

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: Oh, you roguish fellow! I do love you for your drolleries.
sp.stage: [She sways in a gust of laughter.]

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: You mock me cruelly. I would lose this head.

sp.speaker: CADENCE
sp.p: He wishes to lose his head.

sp.speaker: CHALICE
sp.p: Verily, he is the merriest ass mine eyes have looked upon.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Give me air! give me air!

sp.speaker: DULCET
sp.p: If 'tis an heir you are seeking, pray take me. I am as poor as a cathedral mousie.

sp.speaker: MELODY
sp.p: Ah, Dulcet, think you twice. What if you should inherit those generous ears?

sp.speaker: DULCET
sp.p: I could drink in sweet sounds by the hogshead.

sp.speaker: CADENCE
sp.p: Or that prodigal nosey?

sp.speaker: DULCET
sp.p: I could follow it and never get lost.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Give me air! give me air!

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: 'Tis not an heir he wishes--'tis atmosphere in motion.
sp.stage: [They wave their tiny fans about him in playful solicitude.]

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Cease your fooleries! Have you no hearts?

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.stage: [Importantly.]
sp.p: Yea, I am growing one,--a veritable mother-heart.
sp.stage: [The FAIRIES hang their heads.]

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Then by that heart, I conjure you to hear me. l am full of misery because this ass-head hath been clapped upon my shoulders and clings thereto like a million leeches.

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: O thou poor dear! Come thou here and be comforted. Cadence! Dulcet! Chalice! Melody! Stand you back. You have no hearts and cannot know how this afflicted gentleman doth suffer. [The FAIRIES sulk in the background. TITANIA leads SIR THOMAS to the knoll and seating him, caresses his head tenderly.] Thou poor Ass! Titania's heart waxeth fuller and stronger with each glance at thee. [SIR THOMAS gives a huge sigh.] Here! put thy head upon my shoulder. Now art thou a peaceful Ass.
sp.stage: [Tinkle of bells. Enter OBERON, ROBIN and the PUCKS. At the sight of TITANIA and SIR THOMAS, OBERON pauses, dumb with rage, hand on sword-hilt.]

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Is not my head heavy for your delicate shoulders?

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: Nay, most gentle and sympathetic Ass, not heavy--but thy poor ears are over-large and hairy. [She gives her head a slight shake and blows a trifle of air through her lips. Another sigh escapes SIR THOMAS.] Yet are they shapely ears, monstrous shapely ears, and soft, oh soft, as the Humble Bee's waistcoat.

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.p: Leave that odious monster!
sp.stage: [TITANIA leaps to her feet.]

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: Oberon!

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.stage: [Hopping about gleefully.]
sp.p: A brawl! a brawl! I do love a brawl!

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.stage: [To ROBIN.]
sp.p: You bedlam! [ROBIN and the PUCKS laugh and play leap frog.] Come, Fairies, our feet shall not tread the same grasses as Oberon.

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.p: Titania,--

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: Come, Fairies, come.
sp.stage: [Exeunt TITANIA and the FAIRIES.]

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.stage: [Pointing to SIR THOMAS.]
sp.p: See the silly monster!

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: 'Tis a dignified, solem Ass. Mayhap he will smile for us.
sp.stage: [Tickles him with a twig.]

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Cease your torments.

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.p: How chances it you are in the soft graces of our Queen?

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: She but strove to comfort me.

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.p: You know otherwise, you doleful donkey.

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: Methinks he is a lying Ass.

sp.speaker: PUCKS
sp.p: A lying Ass!

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p:
Mock me no further. Take this effigy from my shoulders and by my goodly acres I will serve you to
the top of your bent. I did but put it on to make sport for Queen Bess, and dearly have I rued it.

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.p: Think you he speaks true?

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: He hath the eamarks o' something upon him.

sp.speaker: COWSLIP
sp.p: An they be the earmarks o' truth, then doth he speak a large, buxom truth.

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: He seemeth more goose than ass.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: But take off this hairy helmet and you may call me what you will.

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.p: I have a fancy to believe you. You are so vile to look upon, our Queen could not have been moved by aught but disgust or pity. Are you ready to hearken to terms?

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Yea, right ready.

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.p: A little Indian boy with a skin like brozne has been stolen.

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: By a lad and lass named Will and Betsy.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: I know the lad. He has poached at Charlecote.

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.p: I am fain to have the babe. Keep wide open your eyes and patrol a part of the Forest this night. If you espy him, seize him. Should you find the wench and colt, take them prisoner and hold them till I come.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: It shall be done, my word on 't.

sp.speaker: OBERON

lg.l: Then, by the moontide bowing down,
Rid thy noddle of its crown.

sp.stage: [OBERON touches the mask with his sword and SIR THOMAS lifts it off. He gives his head a huge shake and takes a deep breath of fresh air.]

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: I lose my head that I may find it.

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.p: Fare you well. Remember!
sp.stage: [They salute with their swords, then sheathe them.
Exeunt OBERON and PUCKS, left. SIR THOMAS takes another deep breath, feels his neck with pleasure, and drawing his sword, goes off, right.

div2.stage: Enter FILCH, rear. He looks about him, puts his tray near the knoll and dropping beside it takes the INDIAN BOY from his sack and cossets him.]

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p:
There, little recklin, no bigger than a fairy's minute, now shall we have a cuddle-time together. Whilst so wee, in my sack must you ride, as brave and snug as the Lord Mayor o' London Town. When you get higher and shed your pinny for strides, you shall jog along at my side and wheedle trade for us. I'll prank you up in all the bravery o' the shops and you'll never have call to blush for the two on us. [The baby cries.] Hush, you anointed bad one! Dry you up and you shall be fed full o' stuffed chine o' pork, with now and then a dash of roasted crabs. [Louder cries.] Hushaby, hush! I may have to warm your sallow skin wi' the flat o' my hand if you still not your squawks. [More cries.] I have it! You need to cut your wee bit teeth. Here's the very trick. [Takes from his sack the QUEEN'S crown.] There, lusty limb! Cut your teeth on that. Never was crown put to fairer use. [The cries cease.] I be a dabster! I take to nursing as a duckling to the pond. Now, my collop, I must forage for a bite to eat. First will I fetch bowl of clear water that good fairies may find you and witches may not come anigh you. [He lays the baby in the shelter of the Knoll, the crown with him.] Hold fast to your bauble. At last do I know what crowns be for--toys for babes to teethe on. [He takes a small bowl fromt his tray and goes out, right. Returns and places the bowl beside the baby.] There is the charm to keep you safe. What, little chuck, asleep
so soon! [Resumes his tray and looks upon the baby tenderly.] Sleep you soft till you have rounded out your little dreams.
sp.stage: [Exit FILCH, rear. A flash of red smoke, right, and the WITCH OF WIMBLE enters.]

sp.speaker: WITCH
sp.p: This busy finger hath itched to do its work. [Stirs with it.] 'Tis time I had the brat again.
sp.stage: [Goes to baby. Seeing the bowl she draws back in affright.]
[With her body drawn away she peers at the bowl.]
sp.p: Ha! a foul spot. A spinner hath fallen from a twig and smirched it.
sp.stage: [Stoops to take the baby as WILL and BETSY enter. She stays motionless when she hears their voices.]

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: This is where Mother Hatfield of Pepper Alley said we would find the babe.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p:
It is well we consulted her wisdom, for the White Witch finds lost things as the magnet lifts the needle to its bosom. [The WITCH stoops switly for the baby, but before she can reach him, WILL runs forward and speaks in a ringing tone.] Z! Y! X! W! V! U! T!
S! R! Q! P! O! N! M! L! K! J! I! H! G! F! E! D! C! B! A! [The WITCH cowers and shudders and backs off stage, left.] 'Tis a potent charm for routing witches. I vow I say the criss-cross-row better tail up than head up.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: My lamb! My cade lamb! My fleecy youngling!
sp.stage: [Enter SIR THOMAS.]

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Oho, hedgehog! tracked at last.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: You are a keen hound to run the hedgehog to cover. 'Tis hard to tell whether you make better hound or ass.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: You prate without period or comma, boy,--you are wordy as an almanac.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: You have not the wit to read me.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: I've wit in plenty to have you flogged black and blue.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Black and blue? I like better my own color scheme, for I'll pink you. [Touches him with his sword.] I'll pink you till you're red.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Give me the babe.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Marry, not a jot.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Then will I cut my way to him.
sp.stage: [Draws his sword.]

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: You'll cut it through steel, an you do.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Tush! Your weakling blade is a small bite for mine to swallow.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: It hath sharp teeth of its own and a stout stomach. Have care. [They cross blades in a spirited contest.] Speed you up, Slowbones, else will I have lost and found you again.
sp.stage: [They continue fighting.]

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Dolt!-- -- -- --Urchin!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Pikeshead!
sp.stage: [WILL has pressed SIR THOMAS to the edge of the clearing, and now sends his sword spinning from his hand, playing his own blade about SIR THOMAS.]

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Beware, lad. You might nip me.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Ay, that I might. Mayhap already have I wounded your feelings.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: That was monstrous nigh my ear.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Listen to what it would tell you.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: That time it brushed against my nose.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Sneeze it away.

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Let me go, lad.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Am I poacher?

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: You poacher? Nay!

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Dost swear it?

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: Ay, lad.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Dost swear it by the three luces on thy family crest?

sp.speaker: SIR THOMAS
sp.p: May my luces turn louses if you be poacher. My keeper shall be dismissed for nabbing you. 'Twas a grievous error.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Nay, keep your keeper, and if you would keep whole your own skin, get you gone! [Exit SIR THOMAS at a lively pace.] Forsooth, he's good runner.

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: Oh, Will, you are a wondrous fine fighter. My heart so plumped against my ribs as I looked on you, I was fearful lest it get out of its cage.
sp.stage: [Voices are heard.]

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: Hide with the babe.
sp.stage: [They go behind a clump of bushes. Enter QUEEN ELIZABETH, her LADY-IN-WAITING and the MINSTRELS.]

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: I tell you 'tis a bootless search till we find that rascal, Filch.

sp.speaker: LADY-IN-WAITING
sp.p: Methinks Tyburn Tree is lonesome for him.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Tyburn shall have him. Oh my head! my head! What is a Queen's head without its crown? [Enter FILCH.] There is the mountebank now.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: How may I serve you, Majesty, most sweet, sweet Majesty?

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Scape-gallows! where is our royal crown?

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: Our own, Majesty? Is it not on our head? Our hair is so golden 'tis brighter than the crown itself.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Give us the crown.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: D'ye mean, Majesty, there lives so vile a villain that he would poach on your beauteous preserves? And so excellently preserved, too!

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Return the crown, and justice shall be cheated of its rightful prey.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: I pray, justice or injustice, make me no prey. Filch is an honest fellow. May I eat fennel if I have the crown upon me.
sp.stage: [Holds up his hands and turns around.]

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Nay, not upon you! You would see it were well hidden.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.stage: [Pointing to the crown, where it had rolled.]
sp.p: Here is my crown, Majesty. Wear it till your own be found.
sp.stage: [Extends it to her.]

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: Your crown, wretch? 'Tis mine! [Seizes it and places it upon her head.] Now, Elizabeth's herself again.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: 'Tis most unholy wrong, Majesty. I but shortly refused your purse, asking for no more than one golden crown. May the artist in me be naught but thief an you did not say, "Take it, fellow, and welcome."

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: You mean--Oh, rogue, you'll be the death o' me! So much of sauce have you added to my day, beshrew me if I do not reward your diverting villainies. Accept our purse.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.stage: [Weighing it in his hands.]
sp.p: Another purse! A fat purse! A purse with paunch! I fear me shall grow purse-proud in time. When it comes to women, Filch likes 'em thin--[bows to QUEEN] ay, thin almost to angles, for what are angles but angels with their l's mixed--but when it comes to purses Filch'll angle for those himself, and the fatter the better.

sp.speaker: THE QUEEN
sp.p: A dance in the moonlight to still my pulsing feet! Then will Elizabeth forsake the sweets o' the forest for the sours o' the town.
sp.stage: [The QUEEN, her LADY-IN-WAITING and the four MINSTRELS dance a gavotte. FILCH has removed his tray, placing it beyond the knoll out of sight, and has thrown himself on the ground. He watches them as he chews a twig. Exeunt the QUEEN and the other dancers. FILCH looks about in frantic haste. Bells tinkle. Enter OBERON, ROBIN, and the PUCKS.

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.p: What seek you with such warmth, mortal?

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: O, dear Master Fairy! I am in sore trouble. I seek a babe.

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.p: What manner of babe? A wee babe, a most enchanting babe, with skin as bronzy as an apple's russet coat.

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.p: Rascal, you stole him! 'Tis the one I seek.

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: Nay, good Sir, you mistake. I am an honest--

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.p: Rogue. An honest rogue is honest only when he fulfils his rogueries!

sp.speaker: FILCH
sp.p: Marry, rogue I may be, with itching palm and prigging finger, yet who but I can take crowns from queens' heads, babes from mothers' arms, shoes from the very feet?

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.p: Your steps have led you within the fairy-ring. [Takes of his plumed cap and sweeps the air with it.] Dog of a pedlar, down upon all fours, and from every midnight to cock-crow, go thus till you have repented of your deeds.
sp.stage: [FILCH drops to his hands and feet and barks.]
sp.p: You have strong bark. See that it steer you into clearer waters. [ROBIN consults with OBERON, the PUCKS gambol, and FILCH, drawing near to OBERON, takes the FAIRY KING'S cap in his teeth, and unobserved, trots up stage and waits.] Ho, lads! Let us search to the eastward.
sp.stage: [Exeunt OBERON, ROBIN, and the PUCKS, right. WILL and BETSY, with the baby, come out of hiding.]

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.p: Look you about for a morsel of food for this poor mailing. I vow his very soul is agog with hunger.

sp.speaker: WILL
sp.p: I'll see what the Forest will yield. If milk but grew on bushes!
sp.stage: [Exit WILL, left.]

sp.speaker: BETSY
sp.stage: [Laying the bavy near the knoll.]
sp.p: Rest you, lambkin, till Betsy make herself more pleasing to the eye. I am roughed and blown by my wanderings.
sp.stage: [Sits on the knoll, her back to the baby, smoothing her hair and costume.
FILCH stealthily runs forward, seizes the baby between his teeth, and goes off, back.]
sp.p: You are a precious boy. I wish I could ever keep you near me. [Turns around; rubs her eyes.] Saints protect!--where are you? Lambkin! call to your Betsy. [Looks on all sides.] 'Tis magic! Has the Witch come again? Will, O Will! where are you?
sp.stage: [Exit BETSY, left.
Tinkle of bells. Enter OBERON, ROBIN, and the PUCKS, right.]

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.p: There is virtue in this spot tonight. The soil doth draw my feet unerringly.

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: It makes me light o' the heels.
sp.stage: [Stands on his head. Enter left, TITANIA and her train. She is weeping silently.]

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.p: What do I see--Titania in tears?

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: Ah, Oberon, my heart is heavy!

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.p: Heart, say you?

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: I have grown a heart and oh,'tis a mother-heart. Verily, my mother-heart is breaking for a sight of its babe.

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.p: By my troth, never till now did I know how fondly you have wished for the Indian boy. I thought it but whimsey to cross my desire.

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: Nay, I am heartsick.

sp.speaker: FAIRIES
sp.stage: [Shaking their heads.]
sp.p: She is heartsick.

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: And full of longing.

sp.speaker: FAIRIES
sp.p: Full of longing.

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: Help me, Oberon.

sp.speaker: FAIRIES
sp.p: Yea, help her, Oberon.

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.p: By the pipe of Dawn and the call of Dusk, you shall have the babe. Is it not so, lads?

sp.speaker: ROBIN and PUCKS
sp.p: Ay, ay, sir!

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.p: We shall seek the babe.

sp.speaker: ROBIN and PUCKS
sp.p: And find him!

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.p: My sweet Queen, he shall be your own, no one's but yours.

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: Nay, my good lord, he shall be both yours and mine.
sp.stage: [A puff of smoke and the WITCH enters.]

sp.speaker: WITCH
sp.p: A pretty picture! a touching picture! The Witch of Wimble is warmed to her marrow by scenes of loving reunion.

sp.speaker: OBERON
sp.p: What would you of us, beldam?

sp.speaker: WITCH
sp.p: I thought you might like to know where to seek the bronze babe.

sp.speaker: TITANIA
sp.p: My heart misdoubts me. Trust her not, Oberon.

sp.speaker: ROBIN
sp.p: A pippin to a farthing the old dame hath flap-dragoned the babe.

sp.speaker: WVITCH
sp.p: Hush, jackanapes!

sp.speaker: ROBIN and PUCKS
sp.stage: [Circling round the WITCH.]
sp.p: Flap-dragoned the babe! flap-dragoned the babe!

sp.speaker: OBERON
